p: Of the six nests in which we found at least one BFDV-positive parent ( n = 5 nests of P. elegans, n = 1 of P. eximius), we tested antigen excretion for all female parents. Five of six females (83.3%, 35.9–99.6) had detectable antigen in their feathers, with a mean antigen titre of log 23.6 ( n = 5, 1.04–6.16; Table 1). All of these females had BFDV-positive blood samples ( Table 1). Of the n = 5 P. elegans females with detectable antigen in feathers, n = 4 were subadults (<1 year old) and n = 1 was a young adult (1 –3 years old). We detected BFDV on nest swabs of four out of five (80.0%, 28.4 –99.5) nest boxes occupied by parental females with antigen excretion ( Fig. 2B).
